results.title: Agent Middleware | Microsoft Learn
results.content:
```
from agent_framework import ChatMiddleware, ChatContext class LoggingChatMiddleware(ChatMiddleware): """Chat middleware that logs AI interactions.""" async def process( self, context: ChatContext, next: Callable, ) -> None: # Pre-processing: Log before AI call print(f"[Chat Class] Sending {len(context.messages)} messages to AI") # Continue to next middleware or AI service await next(context) # Post-processing: Log after AI response print("[Chat Class] AI response received") 
```

## Middleware Registration

Middleware can be registered at two levels with different scopes and behaviors.

### Agent-Level vs Run-Level Middleware [...] ```
async def blocking_middleware( context: AgentRunContext, next: Callable, ) -> None: """Middleware that blocks execution based on conditions.""" # Check for blocked content last_message = context.messages[-1] if context.messages else None if last_message and last_message.text: if "blocked" in last_message.text.lower(): print("Request blocked by middleware") context.terminate = True return # If no issues, continue normally await next(context) 
```

What termination means:

 Setting `context.terminate = True` signals that processing should stop
 You can provide a custom result before terminating to give users feedback
 The agent execution is completely skipped when middleware terminates

## Middleware Result Override [...] from agent_framework.azure import AzureAIAgentClient from azure.identity.aio import AzureCliCredential # Agent-level middleware: Applied to ALL runs of the agent async with AzureAIAgentClient(async_credential=credential).create_agent( name="WeatherAgent", instructions="You are a helpful weather assistant.", tools=get_weather, middleware=[ SecurityAgentMiddleware(), # Applies to all runs TimingFunctionMiddleware(), # Applies to all runs ], ) as agent: # This run uses agent-level middleware only result1 = await agent.run("What's the weather in Seattle?") # This run uses agent-level + run-level middleware result2 = await agent.run( "What's the weather in Portland?", middleware=[ # Run-level middleware (this run only) logging_chat_middleware, ] ) # This run uses agent-level middleware only

results.title: Built an AI agent with LangChain v1 middleware in 150 lines of code
results.content: I built an AI agent in ~150 lines of code that asks questions, executes actions, and validates results—all with human oversight baked in. Here's how LangChain v1's middleware made it surprisingly simple 🤯 I stumbled on a great thread by @arafatkatze about how AI agents really just operate in 3 states ( 🤔 Need to ASK something ⚡ Need to DO something ✅ Ready to SHOW results Simple, right? So I thought: "How would this look with LangChain v1 alpha's new middleware?" Turns out, middleware is perfect for this. Instead of building complex routing logic, I just: 1️⃣ Defined my tools - reading files, searching code, asking questions, showing results 2️⃣ Injected them via middleware - one clean array, no manual wiring 3️⃣ Used lifecycle hooks - modifyModelRequest builds the system prompt [...] I built an AI agent in ~150 lines of code that asks questions, executes actions, and validates results—all with human oversight baked in. Here's how LangChain v1's middleware made it surprisingly simple 🤯 I stumbled on a great thread by @arafatkatze about how AI agents really just operate in 3 states ( 🤔 Need to ASK something ⚡ Need to DO something ✅ Ready to SHOW results Simple, right? So I thought: "How would this look with LangChain v1 alpha's new middleware?" Turns out, middleware is perfect for this. Instead of building complex routing logic, I just: 1️⃣ Defined my tools - reading files, searching code, asking questions, showing results 2️⃣ Injected them via middleware - one clean array, no manual wiring 3️⃣ Used lifecycle hooks - modifyModelRequest builds the system prompt [...] model responds - add guardrails, trigger human review, log decisions for compliance. You can tweak the actual API call - swap tools, adjust prompts, modify messages right before they're sent. The real power is chaining these together. One middleware handles user authentication, another adds conversation history, a third implements your custom business rules. They all work independently without stepping on each other. What I love about this approach is how much custom logic it eliminates. Instead of writing dozens of wrapper functions and state management code, you just plug in middleware components. All that boilerplate I was building to handle context switching and validation? Gone. I've been testing it with automatic conversation summarization and prompt caching alongside my custom

thing and uh this is pre preselect like standardized format of human loop and this should be familiar to you right but it's very simple right now it's everything the complexities hidden inside the human in loop middleware. So what we are going to do here, we are allowing to either approve this tool, edit it or reject it. The rest happens automatically. And you probably should be aware that when you approve the tool, you just allow the tool to be executed. When you reject, you can reject it and provide maybe additional note if you want or feedback why you don't want this tool to be executed. Or you can even edit the parameters of the tool and then run it but with some list of parameters. But from now on it's everything clear. It's hidden. The complexity is hidden inside this human in [...] It's hidden. The complexity is hidden inside this human in middleware. And practically that's that's the whole point in and this our financial advisor a agent right and we're going to ask it the financial questions about some test stocks as usual. But if we compile run it let's take a look how okay look at that it's different right now. Okay we see immediately that this hook was added or middleware sorry it's middleware right now. So this middleware was added. It's after the model as this one says and we immediately can see it in our diagram. So what's happening here? We have a start goes to model. If model decides to make a tool call, it goes to this after model for human inter middleware. It checks if this is a tool call and this tool call should be protected. Then it performs some [...] This episode shows how middleware fits into real workflows for AI agents—whether you're learning how to create AI agents, how to build them, or how to make autonomous AI agents behave safely with tools and Human-in-the-Loop checkpoints. If you're exploring LangChain, LangGraph, reAct architecture, or just want a straightforward langchain tutorial or ai agent tutorial, this will help you understand what’s new and why it matters.

I get it—tech content takes time to research, code, and polish. If my videos have helped you save time, avoid headaches, or just made debugging less painful, a coffee would be highly appreciated!

results.title: LangChain's middleware for AI agents: a game changer - LinkedIn
results.content:
is now durable with automatic checkpointing. • I can pause execution, inspect state, or even “time travel” to debug past steps that’s a big leap forward. • Seeing how companies like Uber and LinkedIn are already using it in production makes it even more exciting. 3. Middleware System – Total Control • LangChain now gives fine-grained hooks to control everything before and after model calls. • I’ve tested middleware for caching, approval workflows, and summarization all reusable, neat, and efficient. 4. Structured Outputs -Built In • Previously, getting structured responses from LLMs required multiple calls or extra logic. • Now it’s native. You can bind schemas using Pydantic or JSON, making agents faster and more reliable. 5. Standard Content Blocks • A single message format now supports [...] # LangChain's middleware for AI agents: a game changer

This title was summarized by AI from the post below.

Dhanushkumar R

 Report this post

LangChain’s agent framework is one of the most powerful ecosystems for building intelligent AI applications. However, what sets it apart is its middleware system — a flexible way to monitor, control, and enhance your agent’s behavior. Whether you’re building a complex multi-tool agent, managing privacy concerns, or just want to keep your context efficient, middleware is the toolkit you didn’t know you needed. #langchain #middleware #aiagents #llm #genai

Unlocking the Power of LangChain Agent Middleware   medium.com

results.title: Introduction to Microsoft Agent Framework | Microsoft Learn
results.description: Agents support model providers including Azure OpenAI, OpenAI, and Azure AI. Workflows: Graph-based workflows that connect multiple agents and functions to perform complex, multi-step tasks. Workflows support type-based routing, nesting, checkpointing, and request/response patterns for human-in-the-loop scenarios. The framework also provides foundational building blocks, including model clients (chat completions and responses), an agent thread for state management, context providers for agent memory, middleware for intercepting agent actions, and MCP clients for tool integration.
